headline: Tender Pork Spare Ribs
description: For spare ribs that fall off the bone, you'll need to cook them low and slow. So plan ahead. But these juicy and tender spare ribs are worth the wait!

video.description: What's cooking in Austin? Kerri's fall-off-the-bone pork ribs.
video.name: What's Cooking in Austin, TX?

name: Tender Pork Spare Ribs

recipeInstructions.text: Mix brown sugar, fajita seasoning, and paprika in a bowl. Rub both sides of pork spareribs with the brown sugar mixture. Place spareribs in a 9x13-inch baking pan; cover and refrigerate 8 hours or overnight.
Preheat the oven to 250 degrees F (120 degrees C). Whisk together beer, garlic, honey, Worcestershire sauce, and mustard in a bowl. Set aside.

Tear off 2 large sheets of heavy-duty aluminum foil and lay them shiny-side down. Place a rack of spare ribs on each sheet, meaty-side up. Tear off 2 more sheets of foil and place them on top of the spare ribs, shiny-side up. Begin tightly folding the edges of the foil together to create a sealed packet. Just before sealing completely, divide beer mixture evenly into each packet. Complete the seal. Place the packets side-by-side on an 11x14-inch baking sheet.

Bake ribs in the preheated oven until the ribs are very tender, 3 1/2 to 4 hours. Carefully open each packet and drain drippings into a saucepan. You may only need the drippings from one packet. Place ribs on a foil-lined baking sheet and set aside.
Heat the saucepan over medium-high and simmer drippings until the sauce begins to thicken, about 5 minutes. Brush the thickened sauce over ribs.
Preheat the broiler and set the oven rack about 6 inches from the heat source. Return ribs to the oven and broil until the sauce is lightly caramelized, 5 to 7 minutes.

review.reviewBody: The best recipes! All our guests love these ribs!!!

I just made this for labor day weekend!!!!! delicious and pretty close to the best ribs I've ate!!! ribs ways intimidated me to cook but I followed the recipe to the "T"...... and everyone loved them and went back for seconds!!!!
The absolute best ribs ever according to my husband who is really a “ribs snob”. Made it exactly as stated.

Modified to replace the fajita seasoning with a no carb rub. A previous 1 * review said he followed the recipe exactly and had tough rib that had 2 be thrown out, Idiot. Mine turned out falling off the bone, been doin this for a few years, and these were some on the best (mind you I was constrained by a no carb spouse).

I tested them at 3 hours and it was all much too tough, and the cartilage ends were still like rock. I put them back in turning it up to 350 for another 1.5 hours and while they were good, still not done enough. I'm glad I checked on them otherwise we would have been foraging for leftovers at dinner time.

Either 4 hours is not enough time, or 250f is not enough heat. I'm guessing 325 for 4 hours would do it. 250 might have worked on baby backs, but not spare ribs.

Followed this recipe to the tee... What a great rack of spare ribs, really tasty, they have a really good sticky goodness to them! Thank you for the great recipe. Next weekend I think I’ll add a couple extra tablespoons of honey.

I tried these today..and Boy was I presently surprised...they were wonderful!!! I hadn't made baby back ribs in a long time and to tell the truth I had my reservations about the ingredients.. fijata seasoning??? Beer, brown sugar and mustard...then the cooking time 275 for 4 hours...seriously??? Well, I followed the reciept to the letter, except the time..I cooked them at 300 for 3 hours... and oh my gosh...my family went nuts....so good I will be making them again..Thank you for this reciept...loved it..
Have made ribs numerous times. The best yet! Kids said “mom, this dinner is amazing!”
Turned out great!
Really good and easy!! Will definitely make this again soon

Used super wide foil (18") so one sheet for each rack that folded up tight rather than two narrow sheets per rack. Used muscovado sugar not brown sugar. Made three racks and adjust amounts accordingly. Ran sauce and foil drippings through a soup separator to remove fat. Reduced all and poured it over the ribs for the time under the broiler. Very tasty.

Made these 5 times now and these are the adjustments I recommend. Took them to a pot luck they where the first thing gone by half an hour.


Used only a 1/4 cup of dry fajita seasoning
Wiped off all excess rub, after 12 hour in fridge.
used half the amount of beer and used plain bbq sauce for the other half.
Only cooked in Oven for 2.5 hours. More and they get too soft.
chared on the bbq for 15 minutes.

Wife is super fussy about ribs, and these are here favourite
Followed recipe and no changes. Turned out nice and tasty. Will be making this one again.
This was amazing - we cut the sugar to 1/4 cup and used 9T of “Fajita Seasoning” on this site

This turned out really good! I had to substitute some ingredients but it was very good! I used the wrong pan though and made a big mess getting the juice out of the packets and adding the sauce at the end. Meat fell off the bones though.
No changes other than sometimes I use beer or cherry Pepsi or cherry Dr. Pepper.
No changes came out delicious meat fell off the bone
I freaking love it! The beer made it really tender. However, I substituted Grand Marnier for the beer on a whim. OMG! That flavor is outrageous!!!!
The only problem wit this recipe is even if you make twice as much as think folks will eat, there are still none left over.
The ready in time for this recipe says it’s ready in 16hr, but there’s only 4 hours cook and 20 minutes prep. Seems like a good recipe but not sure what the timing is to cook properly!
so juice and tender fell of the bone
Didn't have beer, so I used Dr Pepper instead. These ribs came out perfect and so yummy! Will definitely make again.
Great flavor!! So yummy. subbed Fajita seasoning with chili powder and Worcestershire with Tamari I had on hand. used Fat Tire beer. baked 3.5 hours

Fantastic results! I only had taco seasoning for the rub so I used that, and smoked paprika. I used Redd's Wicked Apple Ale because it seemed like a good paring for the pork vs a darker beer. I let it sit overnight with the rub, then baked in the oven for three and a half hours at 250* like the recipe calls for. The drippings were pretty fatty, so like most everyone I tried to remove the fat and keep the juices. After simmering for ten maybe fifteen minutes, eventually I just poured whatever I was left with over the ribs. Back in the oven to broil....very tender, very good. Friends have requested the method of cooking and BF has asked for more to be made. Thank you so much for sharing!
Pretty good! Tender fall of the bone! Yes I would make again!
Great
Me and my husband both really loved these ribs. Cooked to perfection, moist and the seasonings were absolutely delicious. He said restaurant quality. I agree. Much better than bbq sauce

was way too much fajita seasing, I used masterfoods spice container and will avoid that rub in the future. The braised sauce just need some corn flour to thicken up. will make again with a different rub.

First time ever!! And my husband loved it. The house smelt amazing. I had 3 racks and marinated the rub overnight. I used drippings and baby rays sauce. It thickened after about 7 minutes. Next time not so much drippings. Lol.
Super tender!!!
Great recipe! My only advice would be to remove the membrane on the underside before rubbing in spices. The membrane is tough and tastes bitter.

This is a very good well planned recipe. Like myself, other reviewers have noted that the writers process is the most important part, and many of the ingredients can be substituted for what suits your taste. Although my family and I think her ingredients are great. I also made it with Korean bar b que seasoning, turned out great.

Thanks a lot: At last (due to you) I have now made fall-off-the-bone ribs - I thought people exaggerated when they say "fall off the bone"; now I know what procedure (wrapping, temperature and time) to follow. Secondly, I personally did not enjoy the beer / malt taste / smell; next time I'll use cola (and less sugar) instead - but that's a personal preference.
Thank you for the recipe. I was following the recipe, I did use the BBQ sauce for brazing.
Fantastic! I didn’t even marinate over night.

Followed recipe with a couple changes. Didn't have honey, used maple syrup. And when I cooked down the juices, ( which took a lot longer than 5 min) I added some ketchup and brown sugar, gave it a sweeter, BBQ sauce taste. Excellent, will make again!

My family loves this recipe. I follow the whole recipe down the end except I don't use the drippings. The drippings gave the ribs a sour taste. So I changed it to after the ribs are done cooking, I drain the juice from the foil and baste the ribs with BBQ sauce. Then broil the ribs 5-10 minutes to caramelize on the ribs. Yummy!
Wonderful, easy recipe. Will definitely keep this in our rotation. Great in oven or on grill. Thanks for sharing

Excellent. I just made there’s with a few modifications. I used maple sugar instead of brown sugar and Dijon mustard instead of brown. I also used Adobe spice mix cus I didn’t have the other mix. Fall off the bone tender and delicious. Will make these again for sure.
Use half as much fajita seasoning.

I am looking forward to cooking this again! I wish I had cooked 2 racks for my husband and me. Absolutely the best ribs we have ever had - in restaurants (12 Bones award winning rib recipe) and at home. Thank you, Kerri!!

It was wonderful and fall off the bone! I used wine instead of beer, and I didn’t marinate overnight and I had to increase the cooking temp to 300 to save time, but it was still great! I also added bbq sauce at the end to broil.

It was wonderful and fall off the bone! I used wine instead of beer, and I didn’t marinate overnight and I had to increase the cooking temp to 300 to save time, but it was still great! I also added bbq sauce at the end to broil.

I used a simple mesquite smoke sauce and covered the ribs in foil and your cooking time was perfect for fall off the bone tender... next time I will take them out of the foil sooner to get the sauce tacky !! THANKS!!!
My husband loved it, asked me to keep this recipe! I liked it too, but for me it was too much sugar.

I made this according to recipe and it turned out fantastic. Absolutely no complaints, except I wish I would have made double. Ribs were very tender, falling off of the bone. The rub and sauce that you slather on at the end were very flavorful and very good! I’ll be saving this recipe for anytime I’m making ribs!
Very delicious tho I used country style pork ribs. The sauce didn't cook down much so didn't get that nice glaze after being in the broiler. No one complained
Absolutely delicious!
This recipe turned out perfectly for me. I used taco seasoning as opposed to Fajita seasoning and the ribs tasted great. No one at dinner chose to use the barbeque sauce that was available.

These were seriously so good, they literally fell off of the bone. I impressed myself that I was able to modify the recipe with what I had #1 but that my entire family devoured them. I followed the recipe somewhat exactly. I make my own taco seasoning and didn't have quite half a cup so I used what I did have. I also used regular paprika, and 1 rack of pork ribs versus two (I ended up throwing away a lot of the seasoning). We ran out of beer--HELLO it was New Years Day, so I substituted with A&W rootbeer. Other subsititutions I made were regular mustard because I didn't have brown mustard, and I didn't have honey--well planned I know. It seriously turned out amazing. These pleased ages 2 and up to 56. You will not regret making them.

SOOOOOOOO tender and delicious! Only recipe change, replaced beer with rootbeer, because, Celiac. Took shortcut and did not wrap in foil, baked in roasting pan with lid on. Doubled "sauce" to bake in and cooked 3 1/2 hours at 225 degrees, then last hour and half raised temp to 250 degrees (Total cooking time approx 5 hours-my ribs were smaller than the ones in the video). Followed recipe exactly other than those minor changes. Served with asparagus and rice pilaf. YUMMMY!!!
I made it with Taco seasoning instead of Fajita cause that's what I had and everyone liked it so yes I will make it again...other then that I followed the recipe exactly
Amazing. Meat just fell off the bone.

These turned out incredible. I didn't have fajita mix so I used taco mix. I also added garlic power and ginger to the dry rub. I used beer in the foil wraps and then broiled with Baby Rays sauce for 10 min. AMAZING!
My first time making ribs and these came out PERFECT! Fell off the bone nicely and omg that flavor!
These are my new go-to!!! I made these for my husband who quickly upgraded me to amateur chef status and later made them for a group- a huge hit!!

I made this yesterday and it was awesome! I followed the recipe exactly. (Except for the shiny/dull side of the foil, which makes NO difference.) Sealing the foil packet very well IS important and poor sealing could cause dry ribs. The meat was falling off the bones of mine, and the flavor was fantastic. I did mix BBQ sauce with the thickened braising juices before caramelizing (in video, not in recipe). Glad I did.

I left out the sugar since we don’t like sweet BBQ. Grilled them over real wood coals for 4 hours. Had some rub left over so made a dipping sauce by adding vinegar and oil. These were the best ribs I’ve ever had!
INCREDIBLE!!! Don't waste your time adding BBQ sauce; the rub and glaze is all you need.
Wonderful recipe.....I only added more honey to the basting sauce.....personal preference.
Excellent receipt! Recommend to anyone curious about slow cooking spareribs. Can be adjusted to personnel taste so always a good thing.

I didn't have Fiesta seasoning for the initial dry rub. Used the 1 cup brown sugar, then added 1-1/2 tsp cayenne, 1 tbsp adobo, 1 tbsp chili powder, and 2 tbsp paprika. Only four hours in the fridge. Did the next steps per recipe. I kept the ribs in the oven for 4 hours but that was too long - next time will do maximum 3-1/2 or even 3 hours. Finished them off on the grill with a little Stubbs to char. They were falling apart on the grill, and they were awesome!!! Ironically, Stubbs spicy bbq sauce was on sale at the market and I had it in my fridge -- didn't even see this video until after I made these. It was a very nice addition.

This is one of those recipes I like to make when I’m having a tough week and I need the wife and kids to chill out and be quiet. When this is served all you hear is mmmm’s and chewing. I follow the recipe to the T, although this last time I substituted a ginger ale instead of beer and it was just fine. My tip: pay close attention to the meat at that 3:45-4:00 mark. In my 250F oven I have somewhat tough spare ribs at 3:30, but by 4:00 the meat won’t even hang on the bone. Perfect is somewhere just prior to fall-off-the-bone. Like it wants to be on the bone and you can cut the ribs apart, but a good knock on your plate and the meat will come loose.
Cut the recipe in half. Served barbecue sauce for dipping. Will definately make again.

This is the ONLY WAY I cook ribs! It is fantastic! I’ve been doing this recipe for several years now. Fajita season is really the key, trust me! Honestly I only use fajita season, paprika and light Brown sugar and let them soak over night in the fridge. Using the foil keeps them moist and tender and allows for even cooking. Sometimes when I have more time or my husband and I can eat later in the evening I just let them cook in he oven for about 6 hours and they’re great! Thanks for the recipe!

Absolute winner!! Made them just as directed but with loose measurements and a cook time for 4+ hours at 325 so the meat fell off the bone. Hubby says this is the way he wants his ribs cooked from now on. This made me look like a rib pro even though I haven't eaten meat in over 20 years. Thanks Kerri!!

I made these for Memorial Day. They were a BIG hit with the whole family. Moist and fall off the bone with great flavor. I didn’t have a fajita seasoning packet so I just looked up a recipe and made my own. I also didn’t have honey so used some apple preserves and a little syrup. You don’t need any BBQ sauce at all!! Cooked on a rotating grill at 200 degrees for about 4 hours and the browned under broiler in oven. Highly recommend!!
The best! Chili and garlic powder mixed with the honey and ketchup marinade works too :)

Wow! This recipe was simply delicious. Everyone really enjoyed this dish. I am so sorry that I did not double the original recipe. This recipe will most definitely be in the family’s meal rotation. I cannot wait until make this dish again!!!
I made it very tender...But I didn't baste with dripping I put BBQ sauce on instead I thought drippings had to much fat in it and I didn't care for taste.

I made this exact recipe 3 times. It makes (in my opinion) PERFECT ribs! I have a grill, smoker, etc... but these are fall off the bone perfection with just enough spice and sweetness! Try this recipe... it won't disappoint!

Marinated the ribs overnight then put the ribs in a slow cooker for 5 hours on low. From there followed the next step: thickened the sauce then coated the ribs with the sauce and broiled until caramelized. Amazing and so flavorful. Finger licking good . Will absolutely make these again the same way. Thanks for the new favorite

Amazing. I used an electric roaster on 225 for 4 hours. (The reason I used a lower temp is because the roaster runs hot.) The ribs were so tender, when I lifted them out of the foil with the tongs, they fell apart & a rib bone came out! I tried to thicken the drippings but didn't have a way to separate the fat so it didn't work. I ended up pouring a little Tastefully Simple Bayou Bourbon Glaze on them before caramelizing in the broiler & it was perfect. Pickiest Kids ate seconds! Definitely a keeper.

These are amazing! As one other reviewer said about making them and not ordering in a restaurant - ME TOO! 
I made one change. I made them during the week so skipped the foil packets and put them in my Crockpot Casserole for 8 hours on low. I love a sweet BBQ sauce with spare ribs so I added about 3/4 C brown sugar when I simmered the sauce and I strained it first. I served with brown sugar sauerkraut that I make for smoked sausage potato dinners made in the crockpot.

its a goodbrecipe thanx, but i dont thin that 120 degrees celsius is enough. After 2 and a half hours i pushed the temperature up to 150 and thrn to 180 and still a loooot of juice. thanx for the recipe.
Yes, I will make it again!

Wow! Great recipe. Easy to make, just make sure to use heavy foil to spare yourself a messy cleanup.
My changes: I used a BBQ seasoning from my favorite Colorado spice company with the brown sugar. I used cola instead of beer. 
Result: Honestly, these are better ribs than we have had out in a restaurant in years. Given how cheep ribs are to buy in the store, I won't order ribs in a restaurant again.
Loved this recipe, will make again...tender and has an awesome taste.

Update! I have to admit I'm not a fan of chili powder in anything, but with this recipe, it's not all that strong. However, I still wanted to try it without so this time I substituted McCormick's Smokey Applewood season mix for the fajita mix. I also substituted real maple syrup for the honey. Having done this enough times, I've made a couple other tweaks. I double the dry-rub ingredients and really slather each rack with the mixture. I see a few people have made comments about reducing the juices after the 3 hr. cook time - I find that if I spend some extra time skimming off the grease/fat from the juice, it seems to go significantly faster. That said, it still takes a good 15-20 min to reduce this to a glaze at medium heat. As I said, I've made these at least 6-7 times and they are a friend/family favorite! The down side is I no longer want to order ribs when I go out to eat, because nothing compares!
--------------------------------------------------------------------------- 
STOP THE BUS! These were fantastic! As good or (dare I say) better than any ribs I've ever had at a restaurant. Thanks so much for sharing this. Definitely will be making again (SOON!)
Made with baby back and it is superb!
I made this exactly as directed and it was wonderful the fajita seasoning was and unexpected surprise

This is a great and simple recipe. I've made this twice and the first time was good but 2nd time was amazing. The only thing I would add is after cooking, remove the top foil, slather them in your favorite BBQ sauce and broil on low for about 7-10 min to get that extra crispiness, texture and glaze bbq sauce action. Also, I cooked them for 5 hours, they were really fall off the bone ribs!

These turned out perfectly tender and flavorful. This will be my go to rib recipe!!! The broiling at the end was too long for my electric oven, next time I’ll reduce that time from 5-7 to 2-3 minutes under the broiler

Did this way but grilled on charcoal after baking instead of using oven broiler. Also for the rub used a premixed rub from grocery store,plus the packet of fajita seasoning that worked well. Added a splash of Tabasco to juices after taking out of oven and placing in sauce pan
Was very good I finished it on charcoal for sure will do it again

I'm rating the method more than the rub, really, since I had no fajita seasoning. I used five spice powder instead. I had no beer either, so I poured some pineapple juice around the ribs before sealing the packet. I sliced a large onion, put half on the bottom of the packet, then the ribs, then the rest of the onion. After four hours the ribs were fall apart done. I didn't need to broil them they were so done. I did brush on a little teriyaki sauce. My default rib method from now on while I play with different spices. 
.
It was my first time ever making spare ribs in a oven, and this was the first recipe I found. It came out really nice. It was maybe a bit too sweet for me, but that is just a matter of taste.

We slow cooked these on the grill, so didn't add the drippings to the glaze (just simmered that on the stovetop to thicken). To me, the paprika in the rub was a little overpowering. I would leave it out if I make this recipe again. The glaze was wonderful.

This recipe was very good! they came out tender and delicious. Everyone loved them. I didn't have any Worcester sauce, so I just left that out, and didn't notice anything lacking. I'll try them again with and see the difference. I did find that half the drippings were plenty to thicken up and reduce for glazing at the end. We finished them on the grill instead of using the broiler. I'll definitely use this recipe again.
Didn't them under the broiler at the end...they were incredibly good; meat fell right off of the bone- husband says they were the best home-cooked pork ribs we've had!

Absolutely delicious! This is my new go to BBQ recipe. Thanks! My only recommendation is when making the sauce into a thicker BBQ sauce for basting: skim the fat, add a 1/4 cup + 1 TBSP of light brown sugar; this will help sweeten the meat and cut down that "salty" fajita taste that others have commented on.
Great. Did not have fajita seasoning on hand so used taco seasoning. Everyone loved it. Also only sat about 2hrs instead of over night and still great!!

I did adjust the recipe a bit. I followed the rub and let the ribs sit overnight in the frig in a plastic bag. Instead of spare ribs I went with Baby Backs only because they were on sale and looked great. I cut the seaoning in half since I only had one rack of ribs. When it came to cooking them I used a broiling pan and put the beer and garlic on the bottom to help steam them. Added the rack and ribs and covered with foil tightly. Cooked @ 225 for 3 1/2 hours for one 3.5 lbs rib. Removed and let set for 10 minutes, heated the oven to broil top with BBQ sauce. Broiled for 3 minutes. OMG this was the best oven ribs I ever had!

Tha bomb diggidy. End of. Make these. OMG.
I guess I should add that I haven't ever used fajita seasoning because I use Emeril's "essence" instead. Still, have made these twice and I cannot say enough about how freakin good these are. My search for the best pork rib recipe is finally over!
Now if I could just find "the one" for beef ribs...
Fantastic-I used the preseason ribs from Costco and followed this recipe. These were the best and most tender ribs ever! Thanks for sharing this recipe.
Excellent recipe! I added cumin, cinnamon and brown sugar. I will never grill pork ribs again, when they cook so beautifully with this technique.

Turned out great! Didn't have beer so I just used 12 ounces of chicken broth and didn't have the mustard either. Still was delicious! Just threw on baby rays at the end. I cooked it at 275 for two hours then ran out time and put it 300 for an hour n change! My ribs have never been more tender !

Rib perfection. I used an alternate spice package that I picked up somewhere that had similar ingredients as the Fajita mix. I'll be using this method again, changing up the ingredients with different spices, sauces, and types of beer to get different flavors.

Love it! I made it for my sister and my grandparents, after dinner there was almost none left! I think my older sister loved it the most! I didn't really change the recipe except i substituted the barbecue sauce, but it was still perfect! I would like to make this again!
